Slotkin‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌                 Greetings,  I wanted to send an update on a big priority: what we’re doing in Congress to lower the cost of prescription drugs.
This is the number one issue people in our district ask me about, and has been my priority since getting to Congress.
Back in June, a Republican member and I introduced a bill called the “Real-Time Benefits Act.” It’s a bipartisan bill, and it will help lower out-of-pocket costs for prescription drugs.
Well, on Monday night it passed the U.S. House of Representatives with unanimous, bipartisan support.
It’s now on to the Senate.
Here’s how it works: insurers would be required to upload information on drug prices which doctors would access through their electronic prescribing program.

Doctors and Medicare Part D patients could then receive details, right in their doctor’s office, on the price of a drug based on insurance plan, the price of any cheaper drugs that would fit their needs, and the price difference at each pharmacy.
Patients would leave their doctor’s office knowing the cheapest price for a prescription, and where to get it.
This will not only lower the out-of-pocket costs that seniors, in particular, are paying for drugs, but it will inject much-needed price transparency into our system.
Price transparency will help support good old-fashioned competition –– which helps lower costs across the board.
Since I got to Congress, I’ve been focused on what we can do to follow through on those bipartisan areas of agreement, and come up with practical legislation that can drive costs down.
Democrats and Republicans have both said the right things when it comes to lowering prescription drug costs.
They have talked the talk.
Now it’s time for the Senate to walk the walk.

FIGHTING FOR GEORGIA PECAN GROWERS  This past week, thirty-four of my colleagues joined me in sending a bipartisan letter to the U.S. Trade Representative, Robert Lighthizer, encouraging the Administration to prioritize reducing India’s tariffs on American pecans as trade negotiations with India continue.
As India's middle class grows, so too does their demand for more agricultural products, especially tree nuts.
Currently, the Indian tariff on U.S. pecans is 36%, compared to 10% for U.S. pistachios and almonds.

Lowering the disproportionally high tariff on U.S. pecans would provide the Indian people with more economical access to all tree nut varieties, while also providing a much-needed economic boost to the U.S. agricultural industry and our rural communities.
You can click here to read our full letter.

On Monday, I unveiled a new report on the links between gun ownership and suicide and on Tuesday and Wednesday the House voted to pass two of my bills - the first on ending anonymous shell companies and the second to reauthorize the Debbie Smith DNA Backlog Grant program.
More on all this below.
*New Report: *Guns and Suicide** [image = As Vice Chair of the Joint Economic Committee, I issued a new report on Monday entitled *Guns and Suicide* [link 1].
I was proud to be joined by Giffords, the Brady Campaign, and people who have lost family members to gun suicide for its release.
And what the report found is clear - access to a gun increases the likelihood you will die by suicide.
In other words, a gun doesn't make you safer, it can actually put you in significant danger.
Suicide takes an enormous toll on families, friends, communities, co-workers and others.
This is a public health issue and, sadly, it's an economic issue as well.
Lifetime medical and work-loss costs due to suicides and suicide attempts are estimated at almost $70 billion per year, or about $1.5 million per death on average.
If we reduce firearm suicides, we would make substantial progress in addressing the gun violence epidemic in America.
Now, the challenge and the responsibility before Americans is to do something about it.
I've said it before and will say it again: The inaction of the President and Senate Majority Leader McConnell is literally killing Americans.
This report makes that even clearer.

*Cracking Down on Anonymous Shell Companies* On Tuesday, the House passed my bipartisan *Corporate Transparency Act *to crack down on anonymous shell companies - one of the most pressing national security problems we currently face.
These shell companies are being used by money launderers, criminals, and terrorists - but with this bill, we can stop that.
We're the only advanced country in the world that doesn't already require that companies disclose their true, beneficial owners when they're formed -- and frankly, it's an embarrassment.
Law enforcement has told us they need this information.
Right now, they hit brick walls when trying to "follow the money" because of anonymous shell companies - we need to tear down that wall.
Beyond the impacts for law enforcement, this bill will also help to crack down on New York's real estate being used to park illicit money, driving up housing costs and limiting availability.
It seems that more than ever before, there are too many dark windows in apartments in NYC at night - but with this bill, it is my hope that this practice will be put to an end.
Too many anonymous LLCs - instead of families - own NYC apartments.
The Senate needs to act to pass this bill without delay.

*Reauthorizing the Debbie Smith DNA Backlog Grant Program* Across the country, DNA evidence sits in a backlog because forensic labs don't have the resources they need to process it, denying justice to victims of violent crime.
So, in 2004, I wrote and passed the Debbie Smith Act - which at the time was called the "the most important anti-rape legislation ever signed into law."

The Debbie Smith Act authorization expired on September 30, and we must act quickly to reauthorize it to make sure that this successful program continues to help solve and prevent violent crime and protect survivors.
This grant funding keeps rapists and other criminals off the streets.
And perhaps more importantly, it can deliver some measure of justice to survivors of violence.
The Senate needs to pass and send this bill to the President's desk immediately.
As always, your concerns still and always will remain my top priority.
Please do not hesitate to email me through my website [link 2]*.
Hello all, This was a big week here in Washington!
I worked with Senator Tina Smith to introduce a bill to expand partnerships between schools and businesses so students have the skills they need to fill the high-skill jobs of Minnesota’s future.

margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                                            Boozman Bulletin: Responding to the Opioid Crisis on Multiple Fronts   Dak Kees, U.S. Attorney for the Western District of Arkansas, recently brought federal charges against a Texarkana doctor after an investigation uncovered that he prescribed over 1.2 million dosages of opioids to more than 15,000 patients over a two-year period.
These are shocking numbers.
But then again, every number related to the opioid epidemic is alarming.
According to the latest data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), more than 130 Americans die every day from opioid overdoses.
The opioid crisis claimed the lives of 47,000 Americans in 2017.
The impact of this national epidemic has been felt acutely in the Natural State.
CDC data showed we had the second-highest prescribing rate over recent years—enough for each Arkansan to have more than one opioid prescription in his or her name.

It has taken a conscious effort by the medical community to drive those numbers down from approximately 250,000 opioid prescriptions per month in 2014 to nearly 220,000 opioid prescriptions per month in the later portions of 2018—a 12 percent decrease over a four-year period.
Rogue actors writing illegal opioid prescriptions cannot be allowed to set back the progress that Arkansas’s medical professionals have made to responsibly reduce that number.
That’s why the announcement of these charges is so important.
We cannot stem the tide unless we enforce accountability among prescribers.
At the press conference announcing the charges, Kees said "I hope this is a wake-up call.
And trust me when I say, there will be many more wake-up calls to come."
Both Kees and Cody Hiland, U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Arkansas, have been empowered to hold suspected over-prescribers responsible.
This move sends a clear message as to their intention to crack down on this behavior in order to end the plague of opioid addiction in Arkansas.
Ensuring illicit opioids do not continue to flood our communities and state without consequence is an important part of our overall strategy.
Congress has responded to the crisis with a variety of solutions aimed at promoting a comprehensive approach to reverse the trend.

In Fiscal Year 2019, the National Institutes of Health awarded $945 million in grants to improve treatment for chronic pain, decrease the rate of opioid addiction and aid in long-term recovery of opioid addicts.

In addition to funding, Congress has taken action by providing tools to drive innovative and long-term solutions that will spur the development of new non-addictive painkillers and ensure parity in mental health and substance use disorder benefits.

With my support, Congress increased family-focused care and encouraged recovery by supporting states’ efforts to address substance use disorders by increasing access to medication-assisted treatment, health professionals, long-distance care and recovery housing services.
The treatment and recovery aspect of our strategy is key.
Federal resources are being deployed nationwide to break the cycle of addiction.
These grants are invaluable for facilities that give addicts and their families new hope in the fight against opioid abuse.
We have a responsibility to ensure that these investments are delivering the intended results.
The good news, from what I've seen firsthand at treatment facilities in Arkansas, is that these efforts are indeed helping.
You can help break the cycle of addiction by participating in Arkansas Take Back on Saturday, October 26 and dropping off expired, unused and unneeded drugs at a collection site close to you.
_______________________________________________________________________  Quick Takes:    Cybersecurity Protection and Awareness: We all have a stake in safeguarding sensitive personal data.
I have seen the commitment of Arkansans to support cybersecurity efforts at all levels of government, in our homes and private businesses.

The American Cyber Alliance hosted its 2nd annual Arkansas Cyber Summit last week bringing together leaders from across the state to discuss the need for enhancing collaboration to reduce cyber threats.
October is recognized as Cybersecurity Awareness Month.
Read my latest column about the need to renew our focus on protecting our data and the efforts by Arkansans to combat cyberattacks.
Protecting Arkansas Wildlife and Traditions: Leaders at all levels of government must take action to fight the spread of chronic wasting disease (CWD).
Arkansas conservationists and sportsmen are increasingly concerned about this disease and its impact on wildlife and sport hunting.
Last week, the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works held a hearing examining the effects of disease on wildlife conservation.

I shared with my colleagues the innovative ways the Arkansas Game and Fish Commission is fighting the spread of CWD, supporting conservation and protecting our wildlife so we can keep the tradition of hunting alive and well for future generations.

Improving Veterans Benefits: Sometimes it takes an act of Congress to modernize VA benefits, like in the case with the Blue Water Navy legislation which expanded benefits to veterans who served aboard ships off the coast of Vietnam.
In other cases, the VA gets new information about exposure to toxins or side effects that makes veterans eligible for additional benefits, which opens the door for revising the department's policy.

I am hopeful that we can build on the recent momentum, and the recent Senate Veterans Affairs Committee hearing looking at the topic of toxic exposure, to ensure all of our veterans who answered the call to serve get the care they have earned.
Welcoming an Arkansan as Guest Chaplain: I was pleased to welcome Dr. Robert Lewis, the former directional leader of Fellowship Bible Church of Little Rock, to the Senate recently.
He delivered the opening prayer in the U.S. Senate as the guest chaplain.
Dr. Lewis is a renowned pastor, best-selling author, passionate speaker and Christian visionary.
The Senate Chaplain invites two ordained clergy members, each month, to pray in the Senate as guest chaplains.
Guest chaplains have represented all the world's major religious faiths.
Recognizing Arkansas Veterans: The ‘Salute to Veterans’ series honors the service and sacrifice of Arkansas veterans who served our nation in uniform.
In the latest edition, I highlighted the service of former Arkansas National Guard Adjutant General and veteran of Operation Desert Storm Major General (retired) William Wofford.
He served for 43 years in uniform.
MG Wofford's entire interview will be submitted to the Library of Congress Veterans History Project.
Connect on Social Media: Stay up to date with what I’m doing for Arkansans via social media.
Dear Friend,   It continues to be a great honor to serve and represent you in the U.S. Senate.
Last week was a busy week and the following is a brief update on just some of the issues I’ve been working on.

Helping Law Enforcement Officers Cope as They Keep Us Safe    WATCH: WMUR reports on Shaheen’s after meeting with law enforcement officials  Law enforcement officers are under enormous pressures as they protect our communities every day and it’s taking a tragic toll.
Nationally, we now lose more officers to suicide than in the line of duty.
Sadly, New Hampshire is not exempt.
We have lost far too many officers in the past several years.
I was at the Nashua Police Department last week to discuss how important it is that we continue to talk about this crisis publicly so we can begin to address it.
I’m fighting for resources to provide support to all of our first responders and their families.
We owe it to these public servants who risk everything to keep us safe every day.
PFAS Health Impact Study Moves Forward And You May Be Able to Help  This has been a long time coming: the PFAS Health Impact Study is getting underway and is seeking participants.

This study, which is focusing on contamination at the Pease International Tradeport, is the first of its kind in the nation and will ultimately help Granite Staters and impacted populations around the country affected by PFAS contamination by shedding light on the health risks.
This study has been a top priority of mine for the last several years because it will help deliver the answers that New Hampshire families who’ve experienced PFAS contamination so desperately need.

If you suspect that you or someone you know has been impacted by PFAS exposure at Pease, I encourage you to consider participating in this study and help spread the word about the need for participation.
The more people participate, the more useful and accurate the data will be, which will help deliver answers.
Find out how to get involved here.

New Law Honors the Legacy of Christa McAuliffe   Christa McAuliffe  My legislation, the Christa McAuliffe Commemorative Coin Act, was just recently signed into law to pay tribute to the legacy of Christa McAuliffe.
Fittingly, it came the just days before astronauts Christina Koch and Jessica Meir stepped outside the International Space Station for the all-female spacewalk in human history.

The Christa McAuliffe Commemorative Coin Act requires that a commemorative coin honoring Christa be created, with proceeds from this coin going to support Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education.

I’m heartened by the bipartisan support that ushered this law through Congress, and I am glad that it will ensure future generations of students in New Hampshire and across the country know Christa’s inspiring story and get involved in STEM.

A Disastrous Decision by President Trump in Syria    Shaheen highlighting the dangers of the President's decision during her Senate floor remarks  Last week, I spoke on the floor of the Senate to express my alarm at President Trump’s reckless decision to withdraw American troops from Northeast Syria and abandon our Kurdish partners in the region who helped us pushback against ISIS’ once-significant territorial gains.
Their efforts and sacrifices, including the death of over 11,000 of their own forces, allowed the U.S. to hold a strategically significant area in northeastern Syria.

The President’s shortsighted decision, unfortunately, gave Turkey the green light to launch an incursion into the region which has resulted in ISIS fighters escaping prison, the slaughter of our partners and innocent civilians, and a security vacuum which is being filled like Russia, Iran and the Assad regime.
When I visited this region in July 2018, I witnessed firsthand the value of U.S. troops in the region.
Their presence helped stabilize this region, allowing its people to rebuild and recover from years of horrific oppression by ISIS.
Learn more about the bipartisan efforts I support to hold Turkey’s President Erdogan accountable for his actions from my floor speech here.

Update from Hampton Harbor Where Dredging Has Begun    Shaheen speaks to Major Mark Gilman, Deputy Commander of the Army Corps of Engineers - New England District while visiting the dredging operation at Hampton-Seabrook Harbor  Yesterday, I stopped by Hampton-Seabrook Harbor, where I got to see the start of dredging operations to combat the extreme shoaling that has prevented boats from getting in and out of the harbor during low tides.
The harbor plays a critical role in the Seacoast economy supporting hundreds of jobs.

Dredging was needed to keep it safe for the dozens of party-fishing boats, numerous fishing and lobster boats, emergency response craft, as well as approximately 1,500 recreational vessels that are launched through the Hampton River Marina.
This has been a top priority of mine and you can hear more about our efforts to secure funding for, and the positive impacts of the harbor dredging here here.
Contact My Office  One of my most important responsibilities as a U.S.
Senator is assisting New Hampshire residents who need help navigating federal agencies.

I’ve worked with my staff to help Granite Staters avoid foreclosure, secure military commendations, deliver delayed Social Security and Medicare assistance, and access VA benefits, among many other services.
If you have an issue with a federal agency, you can open a case here.
If the matter is time-sensitive, you can call my Manchester office at (603) 647-7500.
Here are a few examples of how my office has helped Granite Staters.

Dr. Tim Gardner, Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center:  Dr. Tim Gardner of the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center called my office with an urgent request: a patient in his care had pancreatic cancer and needed a drug recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
My staff reached out to the FDA, whose staff contacted the manufacturer, which resulted in the drug being secured along with the necessary permission to use it for the patient.

Kevin Dremel, Keene:  Kevin contacted my office after he had difficulty getting in touch with the New Hampshire Liquor Commission regarding expanding his cracker business to a kitchen in a local winery.
My staff reached out to the Governor’s office, which resulted in the Liquor Commission following up with Kevin and authorizing his request to sublease the space.
Brian Collins, Ashland: Brian got in touch with my staff after erroneously receiving word from the IRS that he owed a penalty for failing to pay his 2015 taxes on time.
An error had the IRS mistakenly listed Brian’s tax return as having been submitted late.
Brian had tried to reach the IRS by phone to resolve the mix-up but his efforts were unsuccessful.
We contacted the IRS on his behalf, and provided Brian’s original tax return with the correct on time date.
Upon review, the IRS realized this mistake and erroneous penalty was cleared from Brian’s account.

Dear Friend, I am proud to share that my office has helped to secure nearly $1 million in federal grant dollars this week for two programs working to combat domestic violence and two organizations who provide adaptive sports opportunities for wounded warriors and disabled people across Northeast Ohio.

Domestic Violence Project Incorporated (DVPI) was awarded $310,147.00 from the Department of Justice to support their transitional housing program for victims of domestic violence and abuse to help survivors escape from dangerous home situations and begin to build new lives.

OneEighty Incorporated also received funding from the Department of Justice, with $444,042.00 allocated for their transitional housing program to help break down barriers that often come with breaking away from situations of domestic abuse, including waiting periods for public housing and financial barriers.

Adaptive Sports Program of Ohio (ASPO) was awarded $158,641.25 to partner with the Louis Stokes Cleveland VA Medical Center to launch a year-round adaptive sports program for veterans with physical and visual disabilities in the Cleveland metro area.
Lisa Followay, ASPO’s President and CEO, was the first featured constituent on my website.
Learn more about her touching story here.
The Turn in North Olmsted is receiving $41,700 to support their golf-oriented physical therapy program that serves more than 200 participants annually, free of charge.
Congratulations to all four of these great organizations!
Addressing the online child exploitation crisisA recent New York Times report on online child exploitation laid out horrific facts that demand immediate action.
According to their report, technology companies have reported 45 million images and videos depicting abuse over the past year, more than double what they found in the previous year.
Additionally, despite the Protect Our Children Act becoming law in 2008, law enforcement agencies continue to face major obstacles in their efforts to combat the problem.

This is something that Congress should be looking at head on, so this week I lead a letter with a bipartisan group of my freshman colleagues to push the Committees on Homeland Security and Judiciary to take up this issue by holding hearings to address the failures of current policy implementation and find paths forward to better combat online child exploitation.
As a new father, I can only imagine the lasting and extremely damaging effects of online child exploitation on our youth.
Congress must address shortcomings in current law and put forth innovative solutions, including the use of new technologies, to protect our children and keep this content off the internet.
Combating rising suicide ratesTaking a look at the steadily rising suicide rates across our country is truly humbling.
In Ohio, suicide rates among children ages 14 and under increased by 80 percent from 2008 to 2017 according to the Ohio Alliance for Innovation in Population Health.
Nationally, the veteran suicide rate stands at 1.5 times the rate for non-veteran adults, with 6,139 U.S. Veterans dying from suicide in 2017 alone.

To address this growing crisis, I introduced a new bill this week to promote research that can help us learn more about the root causes of suicide attempts, including human genetic, behavioral, social and environmental factors.
Learn more about the bill on my website here.

Congressman Dave Joyce, Representing the 14th District of Ohio Friends, While I have been in Congress, I have seen progress in addressing the challenges our veterans face when they return home, but there is still much work that needs to be done.
Currently, more than 9% of homeless adults across America have served in our nation's uniform, and many of those individuals have children.
That's why I voted for the Homeless Veteran Famlies Act [link 1] this week.
Currently, the VA doesn't have the authority to provide reimbursements for the costs of services for minor children of homeless veterans.
This has proven to be a financial burden to providers and in turn has limited housing options for veterans with young children.

This important bill would allow the VA to reimburse providers for 50% of the costs of housing minor dependents of homeless veterans who receive services through the Homeless Providers Grant and Per Diem Program.
I'm pleased to report that the bill passed the House in a bipartisan and unanimous vote of 408-0.
I'm hopeful the Senate will act quickly so we can get this legislation signed into law and provide relief for those who have so selflessly served our country.
But that's not the only good news I have for Ohio veterans.
This week, the VA also awarded $292,975 in federal grants for Ohio adaptive sports programs for veterans.
I'm proud to have consistently supported the Adaptive Sports Program and worked to increase its funding by $6 million this past year.
I applaud the VA for awarding these grants to help our veterans improve their independence, well-being and quality of life through adaptive sports and therapeutic programs.
Learn more here [link 2].
*Working to End Violence Against Women* During my more than 25 years as a prosecutor, I encountered my fair share of terrible crimes, but few haunt me more than those of sexual violence.

Sadly, more than 10 million Americans become victims of domestic violence each year and in 2015 alone, the Ohio Office of Criminal Justice Services reported that there were 8,447 sexual assault victims - and that's not including the estimated 63% of sexual assaults that go unreported.
That's why I have been proud to reauthorize the historic Violence Against Women Act both times it has come up for a vote since you sent me to Washington.
Since its enactment in 1995, VAWA has protected millions from domestic abuse, sexual violence and stalking.
It has accomplished that in part through numerous grant programs aimed at developing our nation's capacity to both strengthen victim services and hold offenders accountable.

On Friday, the Department of Justice's Office on Violence Against Women, which administers many of those grant programs, awarded the Ohio Alliance to End Sexual Violence [link 3] (which is located in Independence, Ohio) $151,242 to help combat these horrific crimes in our communities.

As a loving husband and father, as well as the Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Task Force to End Sexual Violence, I will continue to do everything in my power to eradicate the threat posed by any and all forms of sexual and domestic violence.

*Standing with Hong Kong, Standing for Freedom* On Tuesday, I was proud to be one of the Members of Congress who voted to ensure America stands with Hong Kong and the values of freedom by passing the PROTECT Hong Kong Act [link 4], the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act [link 5], and H.Res.
543 [link 6], which condemns China's interference in Hong Kong's affairs and supports the people of Hong Kong's right to protest.
Even before the latest protests, the U.S. State Department reported that rights and liberties in Hong Kong had diminished.

By passing these bills, the U.S. House of Representatives has made it clear that we support the people of Hong Kong and admire their courage for continuing to advocate for self-governance and the right to freedom.

October 18, 2019 Congressman Bill Flores Discusses This Week in Washington U.S. Representative Bill Flores issued the following statements regarding the Energy and Commerce Committees consideration of H.R.
3, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act; and the House Democrats impeachment process: H.R.
3 "There is no question that Americans are paying too much for prescription drugs.
There are steps Congress can take to help our seniors and hardworking families, yet, Speaker Pelosi continues to ignore calls for a bipartisan solution to address rising costs.
Instead, Speaker Pelosi is working to appease the most extreme socialist members of her party and radical special interest groups.

In doing so, Democrats are putting politics over progress by jamming a half-baked bill through the committee process and denying members the opportunity to further examine or work across the aisle to improve the bill.
"The Energy and Commerce Committee has a well-established history of working in a bipartisan manner to pass important legislation, but H.R.
3 falls woefully short of that standard  passing out of committee along party lines.
Pelosis partisan prescription drug bill puts forth a socialist, government-controlled approach to address prescription drug costs.
It allows the government, through an unconstitutional taking,to nationalize the prescription drug industry by imposing draconian taxes on drug manufacturers.

According to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, this legislation would have a chilling effect on vital life-saving medical innovation, driving both investment and jobs overseas to places like China, while potentially compromising the oversight and safety of prescription drugs.

"Rather than continuing to push this socialist prescription drug bill through the House, that will be dead-on-arrival in the Senate, House Democrats should work with Republicans, as they have previously done, on bipartisan solutions that promote competition, lower out-of-pockets costs for patients and increase transparency and accountability in drug pricing."
Impeachment Process "This week, the House reconvened after a two-week district work period.

During the work period, the consistent message that I heard from hardworking Texans was that they want to see the House work on the priorities that they care about most - securing our border, fixing our broken immigration system, approving the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, addressing prescription drug prices, improving our health care system and continuing Americas energy dominance in an environmentally responsible manner.
Unfortunately, Speaker Pelosi and House Democrats had other plans.
They spent the two-week work period in Washington behind closed doors playing political games with their continued attacks on the President through their sham impeachment process.
Instead of voting to authorize an impeachment inquiry, Democrats continue to bring in their cherry-picked witnesses and question them behind closed doors, away from the view of the American public.

"While this whole process reeks of nontransparent partisanship, the Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Adam Schiff, took his actions to another level when he lied to the American people about his committee not having contact with the whistleblower.

Additionally, Representative Schiff fabricated a story in which he deliberately mischaracterized events that happened and is leaking snippets of information to fit the Democrats false impeachment narrative.
Given that Representative Schiff continues to mislead the American people, I joined my fellow colleagues in sponsoring a resolution to condemn and censure him.

"If House Democrats are so confident in their move to impeach, they should be doing so in an open and transparent manner that ensures that the minority party has equal rights and privileges to engage and participate in all aspects of the process so that the American people know the true facts.

Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy recently requested that Speaker Pelosi suspend the impeachment inquiry until she answered questions regarding the establishment of equitable rules and procedures  something that has been done in previous impeachment inquiries.
Speaker Pelosi has continued to operate in the dark and refused to answer Leader McCarthys line of questioning about establishing fair and transparent procedures.
This process is damaging to the American people and is an afront to fundamental fairness.
The Speakers actions have been carried out in an illegitimate way that violates basic fairness and lacks due process.
"This week, Speaker Pelosi announced that she will not bring legislation to establish guidelines for this impeachment process to the House floor for a vote.
Instead, House Democrats are choosing to hide facts from the American people and continue this opaque impeachment process.

In doing so, House Democrats are overlooking the opportunities the American people have given us to help them by working in a bipartisan manner on the issues that hardworking American families care about most.
This week, I spoke in the Education and Labor Committee during the Markup of H.R.

3, and offered an amendment to promote medical breakthroughs in the ongoing fight against Alzheimer's, by excluding drugs used to treat or cure the disease from the list of drugs the Health and Homeland Security can select for government price controls.

With one in four Americans struggling to afford their medications, it is incumbent on members of Congress to push for bipartisan solutions to lower the cost of prescription drugs for patients and families.
My amendment ensures ongoing research to end Alzheimer’s disease for patients and families will not be endangered or stifled by H.R.
Watch my full remarks here.

Passing Legislation to Impose Sanctions Against Turkey  This week, I joined House Republican Conference Chair Rep. Liz Cheney and over 90 of my Republican colleagues to introduce and pass legislation to impose sanctions against Turkey in response to Ankara’s military offensive against U.S.-allied Kurdish forces in Northern Syria.

After recently returning from a Congressional Delegation visit to Turkey, Afghanistan, and the Syria-Jordan border—which included meetings with foreign government leaders and our own U.S. security and intelligence leadership, it is clear that terrorist groups still pose a serious threat to this region’s instability and our own national security.
Any actions to increase the instability of Syria must be met with adequate consequence.
That is why I support imposing sanctions on Turkey.

While this is an important first step to prevent further instability in the region, I will continue to work with my colleagues in the House Armed Services Committee to continue to work together to develop a long-term strategy.
Read the full text of the legislation here.
Standing with Hong Kong  In this new era of great power competition, authoritarian regimes seek to undermine democracies and suppress human rights.
Hong Kong’s cry for democracy is being stifled by China.
I was proud to support their voice and pass 3 bills this week to recognize & protect Hong Kong’s autonomy.
The Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act directs various U.S. agencies to assess whether China has eroded Hong Kong's civil liberties and protected rule of law.
The Protect Hong Kong Act will bar the Hong Kong Police from using tear gas, pepper spray, and batons on those protesting unjust treatment and asserting their right to freedom.
The Resolution to condemn China's interference in Hong Kong's affairs and support the right to protest calls on Hong Kong's government to begin negotiations to address the protester's demands.
America stands with Hong Kong, and the values of freedom, democracy, and self-governance.
The actions of the Chinese government are criminal, indefensible, and will not be tolerated.
I was proud to vote in support of these bills, and for the people of Hong Kong.
Announcing Funding for Town of Potsdam  This week, I announced a $3,125,000 Water and Environmental Program Grant from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) for the town of Potsdam.
They will receive an additional loan totaling $1,657,000.

The project includes a 200,000-gallon water storage tank that will be included to provide the average daily demand of 22,500 gallons as well as fire flows for the users along the proposed Rt 56 water district.
It also services individuals who currently have individual dug or drilled wells.
Dear Neighbor,  The Medicare Open Enrollment 2019 season began Tuesday, October 15th and ends Saturday, December 7th.
Medicare health and drug plan providers can make changes annually on matters like cost, coverage, and what pharmacies are in network.
During the open enrollment season, all Medicare customers can change their health plans and prescription drug coverage for the following year to better meet their needs.

If you're over 65 (or turning 65 in the next 3 months) and not already getting benefits from Social Security, you need to sign up to get Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance) and Part B (Medical Insurance).
You won't get Medicare automatically.
Medicare beneficiaries can use the new Medicare Plan Finder to review their coverage choices and decide on the options that best fit their health needs for 2020.

The redesigned Medicare Plan Finder makes it easier for beneficiaries to:  • Compare pricing between Original Medicare, Medicare prescription drug plans, Medicare Advantage plans, and Medicare Supplement Insurance (Medigap) policies; • Compare coverage options on their smartphones and tablets; • Get plan costs and benefits, including which Medicare Advantage plans offer extra benefits; and • Build a personal drug list that is more accurate and find Medicare Part D prescription drug coverage that best meets their needs.
The new Plan Finder is just one of several resources available to support Medicare beneficiaries with decisions about their coverage options.
Information on coverage options is also available through 1-800-MEDICARE, the State Health Insurance Assistance Program, the Medicare & You handbook, or consultations with a trusted agent or broker.
As always, if you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact my District Office staff at 301-354-1000.

Click here to learn more.

November 11th – December 9th - Federal Employee Health Benefits Open Season    If you are a federal government employee and would like to enroll or re-enroll in a federal employee health benefits plan you may do so within this period.

News from Representative Waltz        October 17, 2019                             Thank you for reading my newsletter!

Dear Lindsey,  As my constituent in the 39th Congressional District, I want to make sure you and your family are aware that the annual Open Enrollment period for both Medicare and Covered California is currently underway.
The Open Enrollment period occurs annually to give beneficiaries the chance to reevaluate your current healthcare coverage and determine whether it is still the best plan for you and your family.
Your benefits may be changing for next year so be sure to carefully review any notices from your plan.
Additionally, each year brings new health coverage options that may have better coverage at lower costs.
Now is the time to compare the plans available, and shopping around could mean extra savings for you and your family!
Medicare Enrollment: October 15, 2019 - December 7, 2019 If you are 65 or older, you most likely qualify for Medicare coverage.
The Medicare Open Enrollment period will run from now through December 7, 2019.
The Medicare Open Enrollment period gives you the chance to switch to a new plan that fits all of your healthcare needs.

For instance:   You may wish to switch from Original Medicare to Medicare Advantage, or vice versa, after examining coverage benefits; Beneficiaries may wish to switch from one Medicare Advantage or Medicare Part D prescription drug plan to another after comparing pricing; or Beneficiaries who have yet to enroll in a Medicare Part D prescription drug plan may wish to enroll now.

There are a number of resources available to help you and your family find the best coverage that meets your unique healthcare needs:   Visit the newly updated Medicare Plan Finder (available online here) to learn about and compare coverage options and shop for health and drug plans.

If you need help navigating the new site, please watch the official overview of the site for a quick tutorial (watch the video here); Look at your most recent “Medicare & You” handbook (available online in English and Spanish here).

You should also carefully review any information you get from your current plan, including the “Annual Notice of Change” letter; Call 1-800-MEDICARE (1-800-633-4227) and say “Agent.” TTY users can call 1-877-486-2048.
Help is available 24 hours a day, including weekends.

If you need help in a language other than English or Spanish, let the customer service representative know the language; Get free personalized health insurance counseling through the California Health Insurance Counseling and Advocacy Program (HICAP).
Find out more about these services and where your closest office is online here or by phone at 1-800-677-1116.

Covered California (ACA) Enrollment: October 15, 2019 - January 15, 2020 This year, Covered California is offering additional subsidies to qualifying individuals and families to reduce premiums costs.

Specifically, individuals earning up to $74,940, couples earning up to $101,460, and families of four earning up to $154,500 are now eligible for premium assistance if you purchase a plan through the marketplace.
This means that approximately 229,000 more Californians are newly eligible to receive subsidies to bring down the cost of their monthly premiums.

Additionally, Covered California indicates that “customers who shop around when enrollment for 2020 plans opens on October 15 could reduce their premiums by as much as 16.5%.”  There are a number of resources available to help you and your family find the best coverage to meet your unique healthcare needs:   Visit Covered California online at  to compare plans and explore assistance that is available; Call Covered California’s Service Center at (800) 300-1506.

To avoid long hold times, you can have a certified enroller contact you through the ‘Help on Demand’ feature; Free, confidential assistance is available from more than 20,000 certified agents and enrollers throughout California who stand ready to assist you, and can be found here.
My Fullerton District Office is also available to assist you at 714-459-4575 if you have any questions or need help connecting you with personalized guidance.

Although we are prohibited from directly enrolling individuals in health insurance plans, we can help connect you with resources - including free, confidential and expert help in our community - to help you make these personal decisions.
I also encourage you to stay engaged and up to date on upcoming events by signing up for my newsletter here and sharing this email with your friends and family.
Also, stay in touch by following me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, our handle is @RepGilCisneros.
Congressman Richard Hudson, 8th District of North Carolina *Friends, * *We are all getting older.
*There are no ifs, ands or buts about it.
People say with age comes more wisdom and more kindness - and a lot of wrinkles and grey hair.
* As the stories we tell our kids get longer and longer, our memories get shorter and shorter.
*But as a famous American architect once said, "The longer I live, the more beautiful life becomes."
*Every day, I make it a top priority to ensure our nation's elderly and veterans are cared for.
* I have worked tirelessly to protect Social Security and Medicare for our current seniors while strengthening it for future generations.
I've worked to lower drug costs at the pharmacy counter and I am committed to ensuring you can access affordable, high-quality health care.

*I have consistently been recognized as a "Guardian of Seniors' Rights" by leading seniors' groups for my work to keep our promises to today's seniors and future generations while cutting wasteful government spending.

* I continue to fight for reforms to save your tax dollars over the long term and pave the way for a Medicare system that promotes higher quality care for seniors while strengthening the doctor-patient relationship.
Last year, I was proud to support the *Strengthening Protections for Social Security Beneficiaries Act of 2017* (H.R.
4547) to improve protections for the millions of Social Security beneficiaries who rely on a representative payee to administer their monthly benefits.
*President Donald Trump signed the bill into law, and we've made good progress, but there is still much more work to do.
* I'm glad to see this Administration continue to put caring for our nation's seniors at the top of the to-do list.
[image = President Donald Trump signed an Executive Order to strengthen Medicare.
*On October 3, President Trump doubled down on that commitment by issuing an executive order to protect and improve Medicare for our nation's seniors.
*In his announcement, President Trump said he will continue to build on aspects of the program that work well, including the market-based approaches in the current system.
The executive order will allow seniors more choices to pick a plan that fits their needs.
Additionally, it will eliminate excessive billing requirements and allow doctors to spend more time with patients.
*By doing this, we will help empower patients to select and access the right care, at the right time, in the right place, from the right provider.
* As a nation, another promise we've made is to honor the service and sacrifice of our nation's service members.
* Last week I was fortunate enough to honor a World War II soldier and present his sister the awards he earned in service.
*Private First Class (PFC) Raymond Vick was killed in action in Worms, Germany during WWII when his sister, Jean Brady, was just 8 years old.
I was able to track down his WWII Victory Medal and the WWII Honorable Service Lapel Pin after they were lost for 74 years.
[image = Presenting PFC Vick's WWII medal to his sister, Jean.
*The ceremony took place in Carthage where I was blessed with the opportunity to present these awards to his sister.
*PFC Vick was born in Nash County in November 1924.
He enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1943 in the Infantry.
He served in General George Patton's 3rd Army as a member of A company, 355th Infantry Regiment, 89th Infantry Division.
He was only 21 years old at the time of his death on March 26, 1945.

News from Representative Rutherford  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email                      Contact Me  Subscribe                  RUTHERFORD ROUNDUP October 11, 2019 Welcome to another edition of the Rutherford Roundup with updates about my work in our community and up in Washington.
It is my honor to serve you, and I am always grateful for the opportunity to share information with you about the important issues on which we are focused.

Duval Schools Get Major Safety Grant  I am proud to announce that the Duval County Public School system recently received a $500,000 federal grant under my STOP School Violence Act, which was signed into law last year.

This legislation has already provided over $175 million in grants for local communities to invest in early intervention programs, better connect law enforcement and administrators, and secure schools.

Every student deserves to feel safe while they are at school, and every parent deserves the peace of mind that comes from knowing we have done everything in our power to create a safe environment for their children to learn.

Protecting First Coast Treasures   On Monday, I joined Representative Michael Waltz at the St. Augustine Lighthouse and Maritime Museum to announce our introduction of legislation to designate a National Heritage Area in Northeast Florida.
This designation would provide federal support for historic preservation, natural resource conservation, recreation, and heritage tourism.
St. Augustine and the entire First Coast is home to countless places of historical significance.

From rich Native American and African American history to the oldest continuously occupied European settlement in the United States, Northeast Florida’s cultural heritage sites are deserving of this national recognition that will ensure they exist for future generations.

Veterans Deserve All Care Options   Today I joined Representative TJ Cox (CA-21) to send a letter to the Department of Veterans Affairs to ask for more information on the VA’s long-term care plans, including assisted living programs, for veterans living with traumatic brain injury (TBI).
Veterans who have suffered severe TBI often face challenges with finding adequate care when they return home.
This is especially true for assisted living, since traditional assisted living facilities typically cater to an older population with different mobility and physical fitness levels.
After America’s servicemembers go abroad to fight for us, many return home with physical and psychological wounds of war.
As our warfighters seek treatment and return to civilian life, all options for care must be available to them.
This includes VA supported assisted living facilities for younger veterans suffering from traumatic brain injury.
Learn more about this effort here.
Snapshot: Recent Photo Highlights   I had a great time at the historic St. Augustine Lighthouse!
I recently introduced legislation to preserve historical landmarks like the Lighthouse throughout the First Coast.
I enjoyed meeting with some of our local postal carriers who are members of the National Association of Letter Carriers.
We discussed the ways our postal carriers serve our community and how we in Congress can support the important work done by our postal workers.
Stay Connected As your voice in Washington, it is important that I hear from you.
I want to hear your ideas and opinions, and I hope to keep you informed on what is happening in Congress.
You can visit my website for press releases and recent news, and follow me on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram to find out how I’m fighting for the people of Northeast Florida.

margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }     p { margin-bottom:1em; }          News From Congressman Bost                      Website About Mike Contact Issues Media Center Services                             The Bost Bulletin Friend,  Last week I welcomed Dr. Phil Roe (R-TN), Ranking Member of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, to join me for my Southern Illinois Veterans Tour.

We met with dozens of former service members and the dedicated professionals in the community who help serve them to discuss the opportunities and challenges they face and how we can help them in Washington.
As a Marine and the father of a Marine, I take this responsibility very seriously.
Here's a quick recap of my tour and the work I’m doing in Congress to ensure our veterans get the care, benefits, and services they deserve.
Getting Results for Our Veterans In Congress, there should be no bigger priority than caring for the men and women who selflessly sacrificed for our freedoms.

In my role on the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee and the senior Republican on the Disability Assistance and Memorial Affairs Subcommittee, I have had a unique opportunity to lead on issues important to our veterans.
There will always be more we can do, so my mission will never cease to give back to the veterans of the United States.

Here’s some recent developments that may be of interest to you or someone you love:     Welcoming Our Veterans Home I was honored to welcome home Southern Illinois veterans who took part in last week’s Honor Flight to Washington, D.C. Every year, Honor Flight of Southern Illinois, a non-profit organization, provides all veterans who apply a free trip to our nation’s capital to visit the many memorials and honor the service they have given to our country.
I am grateful for the opportunity that this organization gives to the men and women who have selflessly served the United States.
Programs like the Honor Flight allow us to give back to our veterans, and I am proud to have been a part of it.
Getting Feedback from Veterans in Caseyville Dr. Roe and I hosted a free, public veterans forum at the Caseyville Memorial VFW Post 1117.
It was a great opportunity to answer questions and receive feedback from veterans who wanted to discuss VA benefits, veterans’ homelessness, personal casework issues, and developments in Washington.
We had a great turn out and appreciate all those who were able to make it.

Visiting the Marion VA Medical Center During our visit to the Marion VA Medical Center, we met with the executive staff and employees to answer their questions and hear what they have been doing to help veterans in Southern Illinois.
It was good to get an update on their work and hear about the direction they are going in to take care of our vets.

Stopping By the John Cochran VA Hospital Dr. Roe and I were joined or our visit to the John Cochran VA Hospital in St. Louis by Rep. Ann Wagner (R-MO) to get an update on the progress they have been making.
This hospital has made great strides over the last few years, and is now recognized as one of the nation's top VA hospitals.
The John Cochran Hospital uses innovative technological advances to provide quicker services to veterans and save taxpayer dollars.
It was also selected as one of the flagship sites for the new VA Whole Health Program, which will help veterans develop personal health plans that best fit their needs.

I was also pleased to find out that over the last few years, over 700 new staff members have been added, cutting wait times and ensuring those who served do not have to wait for the treatment they need.

Talking Healthcare with Doctors in O'Fallon Dr. Roe and I also hosted a health care roundtable with physicians and administrators at St. Elizabeth’s Hospital in O’Fallon to discuss veterans’ health services, issues impacting patient access to care, and the unique needs of healthcare in our community.
Many of the issues we discussed were focused on patient to access to care and costs.
Addressing the opioid crisis, including the need to promote better access to mental health care, featured prominently as well.
Physicians also expressed concerns about the increasing practice of insurance companies requiring prior authorization before providers can deliver services to patients for certain procedures.

Currently, Congress is working on legislative proposals to address the need to streamline and rationalize the prior authorization process and is continuing to implement legislation I supported to help those who fall victim to opioid addiction.

With all of the chaos currently happening in Washington, it reinforces for me why it’s so important that I continue to come home every weekend and use my time in the district meeting with and hearing from the people I represent.
It keeps me grounded and forever tied to our Southern Illinois values.
Whether you’re a veteran or not, I am honored to be your voice in Washington.
Dear Friends, Fall is here and it is great to be back to work.
I enjoyed all the events I was able to attend, friends I was able to see, and new residents I was able to meet in the district during the summer recess.
Now that we are back in session, I wanted to update you on the actions I’ve taken, and continue to take, to make life better for all of us in the 10th District.

Presidential Impeachment: Reviewing President Trump's actions in office  My office received dozens of calls from angry constituents who support the impeachment of President Trump after press reports detailed Trump's threat to withhold foreign aid from Ukraine unless President Volodymyr Zelensky conducted a baseless investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter.
On September 24th, House Speaker Rep. Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would conduct a full impeachment inquiry of President Trump's actions to determine whether they violate his oath of office.
Personally, I believe there is enough evidence to pursue articles of impeachment against this president already.
But I do fully support this inquiry in order to present the facts, so my House colleagues can reach their own conclusions.
I am proud to be one of the original supporters of Rep. Al Green's resolution, H. Res.
498, which called for the impeachment of President Trump on July 17, 2019.
Newark’s Water Crisis: Providing clean water to Newark's residents  I am extremely concerned about the elevated levels of lead found in Newark’s drinking water.
After all, my family and I drink this water with the rest of the city's residents.
The health and safety of constituents is my #1 priority.
Right now, my team and I are working with city, state and national officials to help do what needs to be done to get lead out of the water.
But I wanted to see the issue personally, so I volunteered to help my constituents get clean water at two local distribution facilities.
I was grateful to the staff at the Bo Porter Sports Complex and Boylan Street Recreation Center for what they do on a daily basis to help our community.
I enjoyed meeting with my constituents to hear their concerns about this crisis.
Congressman Payne, Jr. chats with residents and helps distribute bottled water.
We talked about their fears of living with tainted water.
I told them what I am doing to help, but also asked them if there were any other actions I could take to make sure a tragedy like this one doesn't happen again.
There are many actions I've taken to try and solve the issue.
I introduced the Test for Lead Act in Congress already.

I co-signed and sent two letters: one to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (find it here) to urge them to provide more assistance to Newark and the other to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (find it here) to expand access to SNAP and low-income food subsidies to cover the additional costs of bottled water.

In addition, I’m working with my colleague Rep. Grace Napolitano, chairwoman of the Committee of Transportation and Infrastructure's Subcommittee on Water Resources and the Environment, to find out how we might be able to help the city with federal funding or other resources.

Recently, I voted for legislation in the House that would allow communities the freedom to adjust their budgets to provide additional resources to their water treatment facilities in the event of an emergency.
The legislation passed both U.S. Senate and the U.S. House and it needs President Trump's signature to become law.
I believe federal funds are appropriate because what has happened in Flint, MI.
and Newark shows that lead contamination from old pipes are a national concern.
There are dozens of major cities and small communities across the country that could use an upgrade regarding the way water gets from the aquifers to the household faucets.
If we solve Newark’s water infrastructure issues, we create an example and template we can follow when other cities suffer the same fate.
Job Fair for Veterans: Introducing veterans to future employers  More than 100 veterans participated in my annual job fair on August 7th, the largest turnout we’ve had.
Next year, we are going to look at larger facilities in our district to attract even more veterans and the companies that want to hire them.
I was excited and grateful to give back to the men and women who have given so much to this country.

An Amazon representative discusses a future career with a veteran (8/7/2019)    Disaster Preparation and Emergency Response: Making sure we are prepared before, during and after a crisis  Last July, I wanted to see if our district was prepared to care for the underserved and most vulnerable people of our community during an emergency.
We’ve seen how changes in our climate have increased the intensity of hurricanes and other natural disasters across the country.
I don’t want what happened in Puerto Rico and New Orleans after they were struck by hurricanes to happen to us.

As chairman of the Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response and Recovery of the Committee on Homeland Security, I held a hearing on the matter on July 23rd called “Protecting Every Citizen: Assessing Emergency Preparedness for Underserved Populations.” The hearing was held at the Mac Mahon Student Center in Saint Peter’s University in Jersey City, so it could be accessible to my constituents.
The hearing gave all of us a better understanding of the needs of underserved or vulnerable populations before, during, and after a crisis.

It was extremely informative to hear from researchers, emergency responders, and community groups regarding how we plan for and meet the needs of our most vulnerable citizens before, during and after an emergency.
Increased Manufacturing Base: Creating more manufacturing jobs for New Jersey   No area of our economy has suffered job losses like America’s manufacturing base.
In August, I spoke with members of a local Machinists’ union about how we can increase the opportunities for workers affected by these job losses.
The event is important because it gives me an opportunity to listen as well as speak about possible solutions to the problems that face our workers and communities.
Rep. Payne speaks to Machinists' union (8/6/2019)    Legislation:  I have introduced or signed on to support several legislative initiatives.
I wanted to give you a brief introduction to just a few of those measures.
Payment Choice: Giving residents the choice to pay in cash  Recently, I heard that more businesses are trying to get rid of cash as a form of payment for goods and services.
Companies say it will make it easier for consumers.
In truth, it will make it easier for companies to secure transactions, reduce the risk of crime, and speed up the process to serve more customers and make more money.
While I applaud the innovation behind these technological advances, we must remember that they aren’t always good for everyone.
Nearly 25 percent of Americans don’t have access to digital forms of payments, including credit or debit cards.
If we eliminate cash payments, we eliminate the only option for these consumers, including seniors and low-income residents, to buy their groceries and pay for other goods and services.

That is why I teamed with fellow New Jersey delegation member Rep. Chris Smith to introduce the “Payment Choice Act of 2019.” This bill would protect cash as a form of payment and require retailers to give consumers the choice to pay with credit cards, debit cards, or cash.
The New Jersey State Legislature passed a similar law this year.

I want consumers here and across the country to still be able to pay for items “the old-fashioned way.”  Return of Local and State Tax Deductions: Returning tax money to Americans  President Trump put a limit on the amount of state and local taxes that workers could deduct from their federal income tax.
His Tax Cuts and Jobs Act caps the State and Local Tax deduction, also known as the SALT deduction, to $10,000.
Previously, there was no cap on deductions.
This is a major concern for me because it hit the middle and lower class residents in our community the hardest.
My constituents averaged more than $17,000 in SALT deductions last year.
On average, this current law will deny taxpayers an additional $7,000 per year in deductions.
I am working to repeal it, so the hard-working families of our 10th District can get that money back in their pockets.
Donald Payne, Sr. Colorectal Cancer Detection Act: Giving patients more payment options for treatment  My father, Congressman Donald M. Payne, Sr., died of colorectal cancer.
Even though his cancer is a preventable disease, his cancer screening happened too late to catch it in time.
Sadly, his case was not unique.
Donald Payne, Sr.    One out of every four Americans between the ages of 50 and 75 fail to get screened for this deadly disease.
African-American men are particularly vulnerable.
They are 20 percent more likely to get colorectal cancer and 45 percent more likely to die from it than white men.
The American Cancer Society recently found that incidences and deaths due to colorectal cancer are even increasing in people younger than 50.
On June 4th, I testified before the House Ways and Means Committee about my bill, The Donald Payne, Sr. Colorectal Cancer Detection Act, because it would address this issue directly.
Until recently, there were only two methods for colorectal cancer screening: colonoscopy and stool tests.
Fortunately, there is a new test that can detect the disease with a simple blood draw.
It can be done during a lunch hour in any facility that can draw blood.
This test has the potential to significantly increase screening and save countless lives.
Another big issue with colon cancer is how to pay to fight it.
Right now, Medicare will cover the screening, but not the treatment.
If doctors find cancer cells and a growth, they must wait until the patient recovers from the screening to ask if they want the cancer removed.
My bill would provide Medicare coverage for all FDA-approved, blood-based tests for colorectal cancer screening and the treatment, if cancer is found.
That way we can prevent what happened to my father from happening to other fathers nationwide.
SAFE Act of 2019: Making our elections safer and easier for voters  Nothing is more important to democracy than faith in the electoral system.
This is why Russia is so desperate to hack and infiltrate our social media.
They want to create distrust in our elections and our democracy.
I signed on to the SAFE Act to strengthen the security of our elections and the trust in our democracy.
The Act will address election security concerns through grant programs and requirements for voting systems and paper ballots.
Thanks to this act, the Election Assistance Commission will have several new responsibilities.

It must award grants to states to replace certain voting systems, carry out voting system security improvements, find the best way to design a ballot, write instructions for how to use that ballot, and test the ease of use for future ballots.
I believe these actions will make our elections safer and easier for voters.

Aviation Humanitarian Crisis Act of 2019: Denying airlines the right to overcharge passengers during a crisis  In September, I introduced the Aviation Humanitarian Crisis Act of 2019, legislation to prevent airplane ticket price gouging before and after disasters.
Climate change has increased the number of natural disasters dramatically.
When they hit, area residents have few options available to take shelter and find safety, particularly when they are stuck on an island.
During the time of Hurricane Maria, major airlines significantly raised their ticket prices in Puerto Rico.
Many citizens who tried to evacuate before or after that disaster were trapped because they couldn’t afford the outrageous costs.
My bill would prevent such airline abuse in the future for all Americans.
Raise the Wage Act of 2019: Giving minimum wage workers the raise they deserve  We need to give our workers a raise to show our appreciation for the hard work and effort they put in every day.

I co-sponsored this legislation because it would increase the federal minimum wage for regular employees over a seven-year period, tipped employees, and newly hired employees who are under the age of 20 years old.
The bill would increase the minimum wage every year for six years until it reached $15 per hour for regular employees.
It would provide other increases for disabled employees as well as employees who receive tips as a substantial portion of their wages.
A pay raise for these workers is long overdue.
This legislation would give employees a living wage and increase economic opportunities in their communities.

Gateway Project Update: Pushing to rebuild bridges and tunnels connecting New York and New Jersey        Gateway construction area    In September, the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure held a hearing on federal grants for state infrastructure projects.
The Gateway Program, which will replace decaying bridges and tunnels connecting New Jersey and New York, is the most critical infrastructure project in the country.
The federal government promised to fund half of the total cost of the project and then began to backtrack on that promise.
That agreement should be honored.

During the hearing, I questioned the acting Administrator of the Federal Transit Administration on why they are holding up federal funding for the Portal North Bridge project when it is ready to begin.
We need this project funded and these improvements made immediately.
Constituent Correspondence: Responding to Constituent Concerns  The thousands of letters I receive from constituents are extremely important to me.
During the time period from January 3 to September 30, 2019, I received 18,860 letters from constituents throughout the district about a variety of topics.
Constituent Letters based on City of Origin    I appreciate your letters and your concerns about issues that affect our district.

The most popular subjects were support for impeaching President Trump, support for the Dreamers and Promise Act, support for gun control regulation, support for the Climate Action Now Act, support for legislation to support the Green New Deal, support for the Equality Act, support for a ban on toxic pesticides, support for the Social Security Fairness Act, support for stronger rules against robocalls, and support for the Saving America's Pollinators Act.
In closing, it has been a busy time for legislative and district activities.
These are but a few of the actions I’ve taken during the last few months to improve the health and prosperity of all my constituents.
I hope you are having a great Fall and let me know how I can be of service in the future.
Sincerely, Donald M. Payne, Jr.

This week, we celebrate one of Maine’s most famous residents — and no, I’m not talking about Stephen King or the couple who say “buttery flaky crust” in the Dysart’s commercial.
Actually, this week marks National Lobster Day, when we celebrate not only our favorite crustacean, but all the men and women who help this industry and our state thrive.

Folks from away might not understand why we are celebrating the lobster, but Maine people know that this shellfish isn’t just a delicious meal — it’s a vital part of our state’s economy, supporting communities up and down our coast.

Maine people also know that even as we celebrate lobsters, this industry is facing serious challenges — from well-intentioned but harmful potential regulations, to poorly designed foreign policy emanating from Washington, to the looming threat of warming waters due to climate change.
So today, more than any other time in the past, it’s important to emphasize the value of this economic driver, and push back on the threats it faces.
One of the most pressing concerns facing our lobster industry is the danger of potentially misguided federal regulations to protect right whales.
Now, let’s be clear: everyone, including lobstermen, wants to protect this endangered species.
We just want to make sure we’re making changes based on sound data; and at this point, it is not clear that Maine’s lobster fishery is a significant contributor to right whale deaths.
The possible changes threaten livelihoods and lives by calling for expensive and dangerous new equipment configurations.
Even worse, these changes would disproportionately affect Maine lobstermen while not holding Canadian fisheries to the same standards.

I’ve been pushing hard with my Maine colleagues, asking everyone from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to the President himself to make sure we’re not moving forward based on incomplete data.

I even made the argument directly to NOAA officials at an Ellsworth scoping session last month, where more than a hundred concerned people packed into the high school auditorium on a beautiful Tuesday night.
The message from the community was unified: we’re prepared to make reasonable changes to protect this species, but show us the data.
These potential regulations are a serious problem on the horizon, but there is an existing Washington policy that is already harming our industry — the President’s trade war.
China was the fastest growing market for Maine lobsters, and lobster dealers spent a lot of time and money building relationships with Chinese buyers.
But that all changed when the trade war started.

Lobsters were one of the first products targeted by China for retaliation after the President started imposing his tariffs, and this has had a severe impact: through the first six months of this year, American lobster exports to China declined by more than 80 percent, and Canadian businesses have already seized the opportunity.
Maine people are paying the price for this reckless trade war.
The drop in exports is costing jobs and undermining our state’s ability to build relationships in the Chinese market.
Despite this pain, the administration refuses to compensate our industry while it provides bailouts for soybean farmers in Iowa.
This is wrong — Maine people did not start this trade war.
They deserve to be made whole.
Of course, neither of these concerns will matter if there are no lobsters to catch.
That is the threat posed by the warming of waters due to climate change.
The Gulf of Maine is the second fastest-warming portion of the world’s oceans, a fact that will dramatically alter ecosystems and drive lobster populations farther north.
We’ve already seen once-stable lobster fisheries in Rhode Island and Massachusetts collapse; we don’t want Maine to be next.
I’m working hard in the Senate to address climate change, through everything from energy efficiency to renewable energies.
It’s the right thing to do for our planet and for our economy.
The men and women who drive our lobster industry make vital contributions to Maine.

They’re our lobstermen and lobster processors and dealers, who pull the lobsters out of the water and ship them across the state, country, and world; they work in our tourism industry that is boosted by this world-renowned fishery, and in our restaurants that serve unparalleled products fresh from the sea; they are our neighbors and our friends.
When we celebrate National Lobster Day, what we’re really celebrating are our people and communities who help make Maine so special.
So, to all of you who make this vital sector of Maine go: thank you.
Our state wouldn’t be the same without you, and I’ll keep working to defend your livelihoods, in ways both big and small (think emoji-sized), from anyone and anything that interferes with your work.
